qas.question: What are large brushes favorable for?
Whate are small brushes favorable for?
What type of brushes are cheapest?
How can the speed of larger brushes be increased?
Besides wear, what is a downside of stiff brush springs?
What are small brushes favorable for?
What are small brushes not favorable for?
What type of brushes are not the cheapest?
How can the speed of larger brushes be decreased?
Besides wear, what is a upside of stiff brush springs?

context: Large brushes are desired for a larger brush <b6_0>contact<b6_0/> area to maximize <a0_0><b5_0>motor output<b5_0/><a0_0/>, but <a2_0><b7_0>small<b7_0/><a2_0/> brushes are desired for low mass to maximize the speed at which the motor can run without the brushes excessively bouncing and sparking. (Small brushes are also desirable for lower cost.) <a3_0>Stiffer brush springs<a3_0/> can also be used to make brushes of a given mass work at a higher speed, but at the cost of <b8_0>greater friction<b8_0/> losses (<a4_0>lower efficiency<a4_0/>) and accelerated brush and commutator wear. Therefore, DC motor brush design entails a trade-off between output power, <a1_0>speed<a1_0/>, and <b9_0>efficiency<b9_0/>/wear.
